bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, February 4, 1938

div1.p: Hench supplies a list of possible speakers for the Washington and Jefferson College commencement and the Jesse Lazear celebration.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, February 4, 1938
div1.opener:
February 4, 1938
Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison
Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pennsylvania
My dear Hutch:
div1.p:
I have discussed your letter with Dr. Alvarez, one of our con-
sultants, who is rather extensively acquainted with medical speakers in the
country. We have pooled our suggestions. Incidentally, do you wish me to
see Lord Dawson personally? Do you think it would help matters or not? I
expect to arrive in London the twenty-fifth of March and probably could see
him very shortly thereafter.

I think in many ways it is a good idea to have Lord Dawson, as he
is a well known speaker. However, it seems a little inappropriate to have an
English speaker as a chief guest to honor work done by American medical men,
unless you are after a name, which Dawson is. Dawson is no longer honorary
physician to the King. Lord Horner is. Horner is very much interested in
rheumatism, chairman of the Imperial Rheumatism Council, and is chairman of
one of the congresses to which I am going; but he is a short, none too im-
pressive and rather snooty Englishman who did not create a very good impression
as a guest at our rheumatism meeting here a few years ago. He decidedly tried
to speak down to us as the “Great White Father”, and as I remember, he spoke
too frankly to newspaper reporters on landing in New York, making remarks which
were a little indiscreet and undiplomatic. Nevertheless, he is the great “I am”
in England at the moment.

Dr. Alvarez says that de Kruif can speak well if he wants to, but
that he has a curious habit of enjoying the opportunity to slight people. Alvarez
says that he might delight in accepting and then not show up just to show that
he is an independent character. How true an appraisal of de Kruif this is, I
do not know.

The Nobel prize winners in current news are still of course Minot,
Murphy and Whipple, the three physicians who worked out the liver control of per-
nicious anemia. Minot is on our rheumatism committee and I know him fairly well.
In fact, he was here as a guest of the Foundation last week. I lunched with him
a couple of times and he spent the morning with me in the hospital. He is a fair
speaker but hesitates considerably and is not a crackerjack. Murphy is a quite
dignified, very nice physician of the old school, not at all impressive, and has
gone into retirement more and more since his daughter was killed--burned in an
airplane crash last year just a few hours after Mary and I had dinner at their
home. I do not know George Whipple but Dr. Alvarez says he is an excellent
speaker. He is Dean of the Rochester Medical School and a Trustee of the Rocke-
feller Foundation. He has acquired two or three degrees since winning the Nobel
prize but Alvarez and I both thought he might be the best choice.

Another excellent speaker is Dr. Hans Zinsser. Having written the
recent best seller “Rats, Lice and History” he is somewhat in the public eye.
Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison
- 2 -
February 4, 1938
He also has a Doctor of Science degree from Leheigh in 1933.

Alexus Carrell, a former Nobel prize winner, I believe is now
in Europe where he has been working with Lindbergh on the mechanical lung.
His book you have heard of, of course.

Harvey Cushing I understand is an excellent speaker and you of
course know of him, the famous neurosurgeon of Harvard.

Surgeon General Parran is much in the public eye. I don't know
what kind of a speaker he is.
Dr. Wilbur you of course know and have had, so he is out.

Banting, the Nobel prize winner for insulin, of about 1922 or
1923 is not a very good speaker. We are trying to get somebody who is well
known and yet has a vital interest in medical history but this is a rather
rare combination.

Dr. Francis Packard is Editor of the Annals of Medical History
and known in medicine but not to the laymen. The same applies to Dr. Blumer,
former Professor of Medicine at Yale.

If you want a name known at once to the general public, perhaps
Zinssor or Whipple would be the best. Of course Dr. Will frankly is known
more than either of these men, but I realize your feelings in the matter when
one remembers that he already has thirty-some honorary degrees. Let me know
your preliminary reaction to this list and I shall make further discreet in-
quiries concerning your first and second choice.

Is there any possibility that you will be in New York for any sort
of a job March 14, 15 or 16? We sail one minute after midnight on the 16th;
that is, 12:01 A.M. on the 17th. I have to speak at a medical meeting the
evening of the 14th. If you can find an excuse to join us in New York on the
16th I will arrange to get theater tickets for “I'd Rather Be Right”, and the
dinner is on me. We will loaf the evening away and you will be requested to
see us off on the boat. We would certainly love to have you, and are not
proposing any celebration with anybody else in New York until we hear from you.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
